data.name: Counting number of ones in an iterable using all() and any().
data.description:
You have a Python iterable, containing integer values, which are either zero or one.
The iterable can be a list, a tuple, a dict, a set, etc. or a user defined one.

Your goal is to design a function that checks whether the number of ones in the iterable equals a given number using only the Python functions my_all() and my_any(), which behave exactly like the Python builtins all() and any().


For example:

only_n_ones([1, 0, 0, 0, 1], 2) equals True

and

only_n_ones((1, 0, 1, 0, 1, 0, 0), 4)) equals False

Attention: The difficulty of the Kata is to find a solution using only the all() and any() Python builtins! For our case to facilitate the test cases, please use my_all() and my_any() instead.

Hint 1: You may also use range() and another builtin that we won't reveal at the moment but it is neither map nor lambda!

Hint 2: Remember to use both my_any() and  my_all(). The solution is really elegant!
